THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT YOUR FACILITY: 
Risk management and safety have been important concerns at Johns Manville for many years; the Risk Management Program (RMP) formalizes and documents these activities. Johns Manville is committed to conducting its operations in a safe, responsible manner and to reducing risks to health and the environment.

A DESCRIPTION OF YOUR FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED:
This facility manufactures polyisocyanurate insulation panels for the construction industry.  Isopentane is used in the manufacturing process.

THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:
The hypothetical worst-case scenario is a failure of the 35,000-gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (80%), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. According to hazard modeling software, using worst-case assumptions, impacts from this explosion could cause injuries and damage property located in an area between the storage tank and the hazard endpoint. The hazard endpoint, in this case, corresponds to an overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) and is estimated to extend 0.4 miles from the storage tank. 

The alternative release scenario involves a hose rupture caused by a truck that pulls away while the hose is still connected to the pentane tank. This would result in a spill of approximately 7 gallons (this amount is the maximum quantity of pentane that could be contained in the hose.) If a spark were to ignite the spilled liquid and vapors, the resulting explosion could impact persons or property located within 150 feet of the unloading area.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of a pentane release in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program

provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program are described below.

* An in-depth Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) of the system was conducted prior to startup, and numerous risk reduction measures have been implemented. Qualified personnel will revalidate the PHA every five years.  Date of last revalidation completed on 03/22/2017.
* The pentane system was designed in accordance with applicable codes and standards (NFPA, ANSI, ASME, etc.). A Pre-Startup Safety Review confirmed that construction and equipment comply with design specifications.
* Written operating procedures are used for training and directing the work of operators, who will receive refresher training at least every three years.
* Critical equipment is maintained, tested, and inspected on a planned, periodic basis to ensure proper operating.
* The Pentane tank is surrounded by a diked area that exceeds the capacity of the Pentane tank. The diked area is 2176 square feet at 2.5 feet high.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no accidents involving pentane since installation in 2002

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
A written emergency plan is maintained at the facility, and our personnel are trained in proper notification and evacuation procedures. In the event of an emergency, this facility would request immediate assistance from the Bremen Volunteer Fire Department.  
The Bremen, IN plant has recently updated its Fire Alert System. Installed in January, 2017, a new Fire Alert System which includes a series of Lower Explosive Limit (LEL) gas monitors to identify blowing agent leaks within the production and gas loading and distribution networks. The Fire Alert System is directly tied to a alarm monitoring company. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
Safety has been a part of the working culture at Johns Manville for many years. The pentane process is current state of the art and is designed, constructed, and maint
ained to be as safe as feasibly possible. At this time, no further improvements are planned.
